abstract: Microsoft’s Steve Ballmer will unveil a slate P.C. made by Hewlett-Packard at the Consumer Electronics Show, according to people familiar with Microsoft’s plans.
snippet: Microsoft’s Steve Ballmer will unveil a slate P.C. made by Hewlett-Packard at the Consumer Electronics Show, according to people familiar with Microsoft’s plans.
lead_paragraph: It could be one of Steve Ballmer’s riskiest trade-show moves in years.

headline.main: Microsoft and H.P. to Reveal Slate PC Ahead of Apple

abstract: Companies that once built devices to Silicon Valley’s specifications are now investing in start-ups so they can compete with their former customers.
snippet: Companies that once built devices to Silicon Valley’s specifications are now investing in start-ups so they can compete with their former customers.
lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  For years, the process remained relatively static: PC makers like Hewlett-Packard and Apple, with well-staffed research labs and design departments, would dream up their next product and then hire a Chinese or Taiwanese fabricator to manufacture the largest number of units at the lowest possible cost.

headline.main: Asian Computer Makers Move Into Riskier Ventures
headline.print_headline: Asia Gains A Tech Edge By Backing Start-Ups

abstract: “Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel” may be more valuable than “Avatar” over the long run.
snippet: “Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel” may be more valuable than “Avatar” over the long run.
lead_paragraph: “Avatar’s” $1 billion in ticket sales may garner all the headlines for News Corporation’s 20th Century Fox, which released the sci-fi spectacle. But the studio’s other holiday film, “Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel,” may be more valuable to shareholders in Rupert Murdoch’s media group over the long run.

byline.original: By Rolfe Winkler, Robert Cyran and Rob Cox

abstract: The investment arms of large Taiwanese and Chinese manufacturers have created an investment network in Silicon Valley that pumps money into a variety of chip, software and services companies, and some have proven more willing than entrenched U.S. venture capitalists to back risky endeavors.
snippet: The investment arms of large Taiwanese and Chinese manufacturers have created an investment network in Silicon Valley that pumps money into a variety of chip, software and services companies, and some have proven more willing than entrenched U.S. ...
lead_paragraph: For years, the process remained relatively static: PC makers like Hewlett-Packard and Apple, with well-staffed research labs and design departments, would dream up their next product and then hire a Chinese or Taiwanese fabricator to manufacture the largest number of units at the lowest possible cost.

headline.main: Asia Gains Edge Backing Tech Start-Ups

abstract: Apple encroached upon Google’s turf on Tuesday with its acquisition of Quattro Wireless, a mobile advertising company, the latest sign that the mobile phone is the next battleground for technology companies.
snippet: Apple encroached upon Google’s turf on Tuesday with its acquisition of Quattro Wireless, a mobile advertising company, the latest sign that the mobile phone is the next battleground for technology companies.
lead_paragraph: Apple encroached upon Google‘s turf on Tuesday with its acquisition of Quattro Wireless, a mobile advertising company.

headline.main: Apple Buys Quattro, an Ad Firm

abstract: iSlate has plenty of hype, but that name … hmmmm.
snippet: iSlate has plenty of hype, but that name … hmmmm.
lead_paragraph: In among all the speculation about the tablet that seems to be forthcoming from Apple and whether it will be a boon or a gallows for MSM, the name is getting a pretty good work-out. Some have noted that Apple seems to have its leopard paws on iSlate, but reader Patrick J. Shields is underwhelmed and suggested iTab had a nice ring to it. Maybe it’s time to help Apple and see if we can come up with a name. A few suggestions:
